bio:treatment.discussion: Drymaria arenarioides Willdenow ex Schultes, alfombrilla, is on the Federal Noxious Weed List. It is highly toxic to livestock and is native in northwestern Mexico, where it has been reported within a few miles of the United States border.

J. A. Duke (1961) proposed an infraspecific classification for Drymaria consisting of 17 “informal” series that he did not validly publish. Some of Duke’s series were cited by M. Escamilla and V. Sosa (2000), apparently assuming that they were “real” series.

references.reference: Duke, J. A. 1961. Preliminary revision of the genus Drymaria. Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 48: 173–268.

key_statement.description: Blades of cauline leaves ovate, deltate, cordate, reniform, orbiculate, or suborbiculate, 4–25 mm wide, base obtuse or cordate to rounded.
Stems erect or ascending; petals 2-fid, lobe apex not notched; seeds 0.5–0.7 mm
Stems prostrate or sprawling; petals 2- or 4-fid, if 2-fid, lobe apex distinctly notched or seeds 1–1.5 mm.
Plants glabrous, glaucous, succulent; petals 4-fid; leaves appearing whorled, not stipulate; inflorescences umbelliform clusters
Plants often glandular in inflorescence, not glaucous, herbaceous; petals 2-fid; leaves opposite, stipules present or deciduous in part; inflorescences open cymes.
Petals with lobe apex rounded to acute, 1-veined, vein not branched; seeds 1–1.5 mm, tubercles rounded
Petals with lobe apex distinctly notched, 1-veined, vein dichotomously branched;seeds 0.5–0.7 mm, tubercles conic
Blades of cauline leaves linear to oblong or lanceolate, 0.2–3 mm wide, base briefly obtuse to attenuate.
Cauline leaves appearing whorled, at least in part.
Plants viscid; stems prostrate; sepals stipitate-glandular; inflorescences 4–7-flowered, axillary and terminal cymes
Plants glabrous or sparsely glandular; stems erect; sepals glabrous; inflorescences 3–30+-flowered, terminal cymes initially becoming racemose
Petals 1 1 / 4 –1 1 / 2 times as long as sepals
Petals 1 / 2 –1 times as long as sepals.
Herbaceous portion of sepals ± oblong, apex blunt or rounded, veins ± parallel, apically confluent
Herbaceous portion of sepals lanceolate, apex acute to acuminate, veins with lateral pair distinctly arcing outward
